title: Are the ‘Old Vines’ Touted on Your Wine Label Actually All That Old?
text:
SOMETIMES OLD is good. Sometimes old is bad. In a vineyard, old vines can become frail and diseased and fail to produce fruit. Then again, they can produce wines of complexity and depth. According to Massimiliano Calabretta of Calabretta winery in Etna, Sicily, “The grapes of old vines are deeper and higher quality. More intense and persistent both in smell and mouth.”

He’s far from the only winemaker making such a claim. I’ve seen more and more wines labeled “old vines” on store shelves—some of which reveal the benefits...
description: So many wine bottles are marketed with the term “old vines.” But what does that really mean? Our wine columnist investigates.
